awd_titl_txt: CNS Core:Small: Toward Automatic Virtualization of Accelerators
awd_abstract_narration:
The cloud has transformed computing and society over the past decade by providing fast on-demand access to scalable computing resources. At the same time, the end of Moore’s law has driven the emergence of a panoply of hardware accelerators such as GPUs, TPUs, and FPGAs that are critical to game-changing workloads such as machine learning. Unfortunately, cloud migration and hardware specialization are on a collision course: cloud applications run on virtual infrastructure, but practical virtualization techniques for accelerators remains an open and challenging problem. Solutions offered by cloud providers sacrifice the consolidation benefits of virtualization and waste energy. With data centers projected to consume up to 20% of the world's total power by 2025, improving performance and efficiency of cloud infrastructure is becoming critical to the health of our planet.

The proposed research will address key obstacles that limit efficiency and wide adoption of hardware acceleration in the cloud, focusing on two questions. The first is how to build practical, efficient virtualization support for emerging hardware-accelerators. The second is how to make accelerators of the future more efficiently virtualizable.  The PI will develop language, OS, and runtime techniques to automate the construction of virtual accelerator support.  Applying these techniques to cloud accelerators is a significant research challenge. The PI will explore techniques to dramatically improve virtualization support provided directly by accelerators and will develop language-level virtualization support for reconfigurable accelerators such as field programmable gate arrays. By bringing efficient virtualization support to cloud accelerators and cloud services that use accelerators, the proposed research will bring power-efficient cloud computing to new problems and domains, and reduce energy waste.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored and evaluated techniques that enable machine-level virtualization techniques to keep pace with the evolution of modern hardware through increasing specialization. Virtualization is the cornerstone of the modern cloud that enables economies of scale and efficiency through consolidation and sharing of hardware resources. However, new hardware accelerators have proliferated because they have enabled breakthroughs in many domains such as ML, AI, Computer Vision, graph processing and many others. At the same time, the de facto modern computing platform is the cloud, which is operated by providers who rent virtual machine instances to users backed by physical hardware in data centers. Techniques that enable applications running in VMs to use hardware accelerators such as GPUs, TPUs, NPUs, and others have historically lagged many years behind the emergence of the hardware itself. This trend has become untenable as hardware becomes more diverse and more applications continue the inexorable push to the cloud. This project sought and found techniques that dramatically shorten the time to develop virtualization support for new hardware based on a combination of language, runtime, compiler, and hardware tools and mechanisms to auto-generate virtualization support for new hardware. 


The results of this project include a significant number of new heavily-cited findings published in top computer science venues for systems and architecture, underscoring its intellectual merit. The broader impacts of this project include incorporation and use of the findings in the design of production systems software (hypervisors and OSes) and accelerator hardware. Auto-virtualization techniques for software, which is one of the pillars of this project, have influenced GPU and ML accelerator virtualization in industry. Our work on FPGA virtualization has impacted the field primarily by being the first and longest line of modern work on system software support for reconfigurable hardware. We expect our work on improved hardware support for GPU virtualization to lay the path for improving over current SoA mechanisms by GPU hardware vendors.
